abstract.para: This document describes Ireon's gameplay in short.
If you have any questions, feel free to ask them at project’s forum or via e-mail input@ireon.org.

sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: Ireon is a three-dimensional multiplayer online RPG for the Windows operational system on a PC platform. Game action is going to take place in a fantasy world where players would live in a virtual community.
The project is open for anyone interested in development and it is free for all.

sect1.title: Game design philosophy
sect1.para: Game design philosophy is described in the Proposal. In short its aim is to provide gameplay for players of different types and styles, whether they like fights and ratings, or socializing, roleplaying, and exploring the world.

The game should support possible (and probable) change of player's interests during his living in a virtual world. It should provide convenient mechanisms for such a change and for a interaction and co-existence of players of different types in common areas.
Thus game environment should constrain and restrict players to a minimal extent while encouraging positive and productive gameplay.

sect2.title: Game physics, view and control
sect2.para: All game actions will take place in real time three-dimensional area, the only exceptions being some special interface actions such as crafting or exchange of goods.

There will be first-person and third-person views in the game. The player will be able to switch between the two views. Third-person view will have the sufficient mobility, the player will be able to change the angle of view, a direction and a distance to the character.

The player will operate the character using a 'point-and-click' system. Thus player will move the cursor on the screen and choose a place he wants the character to go or a character to attack. In a similar way player gets access to in-game menus and other interface elements. Keyboard control of character character will also be provided.

sect3.title: Game world
sect3.para: Ireon is a medieval fantasy world. Game will take place at Novalia isles (Novalia itself and a small 'satellite' Fjornell isle to the south). There will be no 'locations' in the game, the player will be able to move through all accessible world seamlessly.

In Ireon 'real' creatures such as men and wolves will co-exist with fantasy ones such as orcs and dryads. Landscapes will vary from deadly mires and dense forests to vast plains and mountains. Novalia isle is divided into several regions by large rivers.

sect3.title: Scenario
sect3.para: There would be no scenario in the game as such. The player will not be obliged to accomplish a certain chain of actions to be able to play. There will be only a prehistory of the world that would explain why everything in the world is as it is.
It is possible, however, that sometime in future server's administration will carry out certain large events, that are going to 'advance' history and a world state.

There will be minor quests in game, that will serve mainly as means of character development and money supply. The quests in our game are not main attractions for players, who would hopefully spend more time interacting with other players rather than with the mobs. Team quests are given much larger priority, than single person ones.

The quests are going to be mostly of fedex-type variety. Players will be able to get assignments from certain npcs. It is possible that some quests will be organized in chains, so they become mini-scenarios.

sect3.title: States
sect3.para: There are four states at Novalia: Gillimor, Yiala, Kharum, and Elbra. Each state consists of one or more towns and surrounding territories. Characters of different races (see below) live in each of the states. There is also a concept of citizenship in our world — when character becomes a citizen of a state, that state provides him services (protection, discount at state-owned shops, etc.) in exchange for certain duties and obligations such as paying taxes.

Each state has its own unique style, architecture, and culture. Gillimor is a typical medieval kingdom, while in Kharum there are more close-to-nature barbarians (though they are considered barbarians only in Gillimor). Yiala is a technocracy-like state, where science is almost a religion. City-state of Elbra is a shelter for criminals of all kinds. In a centre of Novalia isle there are Neutral lands, where player characters without citizenship can live in a free town of Allberg.
Gillimor and Kharum are at war with each other, Yiala is neutral (as well as Neutral lands under Yiala's protectorate), while citizens of Elbra are not welcome anywhere.

sect3.title: Races
sect3.para: There are four playable races, that player can choose from for his characters: humans, dwarves, orcs, and elves. Each race has some unique features and predispositions to certain activities. The place of first appearance of a player character in a game world depends on its race. AI-controlled characters will react differently to characters of different races, though fundamental possibility of any action does not depend on character's race. Races actually have little impact on gameplay, rather giving little bonuses here and there. There might be characters of other races in game as well.
There are no racial wars of any kind in Ireon. Heart of a conflict is a confrontation of multiracial states.

sect3.title: Basic character parameters
sect3.para: Each character has basic numerical parameters. Result of almost any action in the world depends on there parameters. For example, strength, intellect and luck are among them.

There is a system of experience points for development of these parameters. Character gets experience points for certain actions. This 'experience' is summed up with overall character 'experience'. When character's experience reaches a special milestone on a predefined scale (character advances to next 'level'), player gets points to distribute among his character's basic parameters. The impact of levels on other aspects of gameplay is minimal.
Parameters can also be altered through magical means — scrolls, potions, spells. These changes may be temporary or permanent.

sect3.title: Skills
sect3.para: The skills indicate how good a character can perform actions. The result of an action is the better the higher the corresponding skill is. Skills usually fit for a whole group of actions. Lack of a skill for performing certain action results in impossibility to perform that action. Possibility any given item's use also depends on having the appropriate skill.
The skills may fall into one of following types:

listitem.para: basic — these skills are given to all characters at the moment of their creation. These skills define actions that all characters need and players can not have a full-fledged game without them. Examples of such skills: short blades, light armor, basic magic, etc.
racial — some races may possibly have special skills inherent from birth. Example: maintenance of weapons for dwarves.
professional — character gets a chance to learn these skills after getting a certain profession. More about professions see below.

sect3.para: Skills can be altered through these ways:

listitem.para: direct use — performing actions, that this skill is responsible for. The more character trains, the higher his skill becomes.
racial modifiers — some races give bonuses to some skills.
'magical means' — a skill can be raised by various potions, scrolls, etc. The effects may be temporary or permanent.

sect3.title: Abilities
sect3.para: Unlike skills abilities define an ability of a character to perform one specific action. Character can learn abilities for a fee from special npc-teachers. Other ways of learning new abilities are also possible.
Magic spells or specific ways of weapon enchanting are examples of abilities.

sect3.title: Professions
sect3.para: A character does not need to choose his occupation once and for all in Ireon. There are no 'classes' in our world, we have professions instead. When a character learns a profession, he gets access to a set of skills (and abilities associated with those skills) that is peculiar to this profession. For example, when a character learns a 'basic blacksmith' profession, he may start to forge blades (he gets a 'forge blades' skill and several abilities such as 'forge short knife' and 'forge short sword').

It is up to a player which professions he wants his character to learn. At the beginning of the game, each character has access to four 'basic' versions of warrior, mage, craftsman and thief professions. Some professions may open access to other professions, that in turn may be an advancement of previous profession or a completely new area of knowledge. Thus a character may be a specialist in one or more professions, advancing earlier ones in the same field, or he may choose to combine several entirely different professions and become a 'ready-for-anything'-like person.

A character may learn professions only at guilds (see more about them below). Overall number of professions that a character may get depends only on his intellect (the basic parameter one, not hacking-the-server variety).
Characters that know certain professions, such as 'blacksmith' or 'herbalist', can create their own game items. The rest has a choice to buy items from them or in shops or from other people.

sect3.title: Pseudoquests
sect3.para: The most interesting mini-games in the world of Ireon we term 'pseudoquests'. To be called a pseudoquest one should qualify as being a) self-sufficient and b) players who participate in it should oppose other players.

formalpara.title: Self-suffiency
formalpara.para: Pseudoquests exist without players. They are generated by system regularly and serve as a lure for players, the puzzle they can try to solve, the challenge they can accept. Of course, without players pseudoquests are of no interest. But as they work by themselves players are free to join actions performed by AI and have some fun and benefit for their characters.

formalpara.title: The confrontation between players
formalpara.para: The majority of the pseudoquests will be designed for two teams of players, and those teams would compete for a quest completion. Usually this is going to be achieved by setting opposite reqirements for quest accomplishment. Players can join pseudoquest by their will and they can choose the side also by their will. Cooperation between the members of one team significantly affects the final result of their actions. Thus you may say that cooperation is a key victory factor in pseudoquests.

sect3.title: Cooperation between players
sect3.para: Cooperation between players plays special role in the game. One would be successful most if he co-operates with others. Solo play is an option, but most interesting features of the game are designed for a teamplay.
There will be lots of different interactions between players in the game. But the main difference from analogues is that in-game interactions are going to play useful functional role. See more below.

sect3.title: War of states
sect3.para: The most global and interesting pseudoquest from our point of view will be based on a full-scale war between two states. Thus, all the players are divided into five major groups: two conflicting sides (Gillimor and Kharum), two neutral sides (Yiala and Neutral lands), and rogues (Elbra) that are hostile towards everybody. In accordance with principles of freedom of choice all the players may choose the side they want to play for regardless of parameters or skills of their respective characters. Therefore if a player doesn't want to fight, we will find a peaceful labor for him.

Global pseudoquest based on magical springs capture is closely tied with war of states. It will give wide gameplay opportunities for its participants. It will be available only for high-level characters. In this pseudoquest several teams from each of two conflicting sides will oppose each other. Interaction between players here will take on special significance. In detail this pseudoquest will be described in the Software Requirements Specification.

Most of the gameplay will be associated with this war one way or another, though this does not necessarily mean only battles. But each and every inhabitant of Novalia will feel an impact of war on his own back.

sect3.title: Magic
sect3.para: Magic is not least of importance in our world. Three schools of magic are going to be helpful not only for mages, but herbalists and blacksmiths as well.
One could learn magic at magic guild. Gillimor, Kharum and Yiala specialize each in its unique school of magic.

Simple magic spells are going to be available to anyone in the world. Some of the most noticeable things of magical nature are teleports (maintained by magic guilds), healing springs, and various potions and amulets that affect character's organism.

sect3.title: Communities
sect3.para: There are going to be several forms of communities for players to join: clans, guilds and parties.

Clans are organized by players and consist of players only. Player can establish a clan just for a formal union with one's friends or develop it into a business organization. If the latter is the case, clan will need to acquire a license for each kind of activity. Then a state or other players will give assignments to clan and pay for their completion. Each clan will have a residence in one of the towns. A clan will have some means of group management and provide nice little bonuses to its members.

For example, clan will be able to acquire 'to-serve-and-protect' sort of license and help npc-patrol with that uneasy task; but unlike npcs clan members will have an option to chase criminal through the whole Novalia island. Another example is 'find-an-item' license. Players that are in need of certain game items but for some reasons can not find them (or get them from other player or mob) can turn to a clan for help — that is for a price, of course. Bonuses to reputation for every successfully accomplished assignment will stimulate clans to buy official licenses. Clans of one state are strongly discouraged to wage any 'wars' against each other — membership in a clan does not relieve anyone of citizenship responsibilities.

Guilds are professional unions of characters. Guilds consist of both players and npcs. Guilds are managed by npcs. Guilds will provide jobs for those who doesn't want or can't join a clan. Guilds will also educate characters (let me remind you that one can learn professions only at guilds). Guilds are going to have public message boards, where anyone can leave a 'serious clan needs a serious mage'-like note. A guild will give its members discounts for any related supplies (cheap herbs for herbalists, cheap armor for warriors). Guilds in a same field are not going to be identical in different states, for example, Yiala's warrior's guild will educate archers better than the one in Gillimor or Kharum.

Players also will be able to create and join parties — temporary unifying entity set up to ease realizing short-term goals such as hunting mobs or working in mines. Parties may play significant role as units of one force in time of great battles.

sect2.title: Gameplay types
sect2.para: Our virtual world is designed for different types of players and for each type we propose individual aims and ways to achieve them. The choice of way and role is always up to a player himself. Here are some possible aims depending on a player type:

listitem.para: be best in something — there is going to be a large system of formal levels, points and so on, as well as detailed statistics of player actions; mage and warrior professions provide lots of opportunities to prove oneself a noble man;
socialize, create an extensive social network, just have a little rest after all — we provide a mud-like opportunities for socializing (politics, organizations managed by players, in-game press).

sect3.title: Action gameplay
sect3.para: Major part of the action gameplay is going to be a war between the states. Organization and carrying out of campaigns lies on players' shoulders for the most part. That is, the players may organize and participate in raids whenever they want to. But, definitely, the most interesting part of warrior gameplay is a 'magical springs capture' pseudoquest. It will be generated regularly (approximately once a week). It will include various actions to be executed by large numbers of warriors and mages. Battles with mobs are going to be of secondary importance.

sect4.title: On murders
sect4.para: Utter probition of murders exists only within city boundaries, all the other territories are theoretically free of such restriction. But in practice there are several in-game mechanisms making unlawful murder highly undesirable for a murderer. There are pc and npc police, carma, reputation, and so on. It should be noted that all of these measures apply only to murders of allies and neutral citizens. Murder of a character from an enemy state is considered a good and useful thing.

sect3.para:
Fights between characters at special arenas with game money at stake is an option as well.
Last but not least players have a choice of joining a dark side of the Force and becoming citizens of a criminal haven, a special city-state of Elbra. Citizens of Elbra can perform actions considered illegal in all other states, such as robberies and murders, with rather mild consequences.

sect4.title: Combat system
sect4.para: In-game combat doesn't differ from other actions, that is, the game doesn't switch to some special 'combat' regime. Combat takes place in real time with a free camera.
During the combat defence (parrying the enemy blows) and continuous weak blows are done automatically. All strong blows, combos, stands, attack/defence priorities are executed manually by players.

At special arenas characters can participate in training fights (not to death) and fights for money. These last ones can be even hardcore (player who loses says goodbye to his character). Other players can watch the duel and make stakes. The winner and players who bet on him will get additional money.

sect3.title: Peaceful labor
sect3.para: There is going to be a large trade system in the game. The players will be able to exchange and trade goods with npcs and other players either tete-a-tete or through auctions.

Players will be able to craft game items. To get good results the crafter will not only have to get 'knowledge' within the game (e.g. learn the appropriate profession and have necessary skills) but also he should understand the procedure of our non-linear crafting itself. This procedure will define the quality, characteristics, and price of the crafted item. An experienced crafter will be able to make things that are specially tuned for their owner to suit him best.
Also player will be able to occupy himself with healing magic, production of potions, search for resources, gambling, etc.

sect3.title: Politics and management
sect3.para: Political activities provide yet another opportunities for character development in Ireon. Players are going to be self-governed to a large degree. Players will themselves take important decisions, and those decisions are going to have a real impact on game world. Players will create laws and see to their realization, they will (with a little help of live team, of course) organize various events.
A character who's executing government functions will get wages, experience points, and so forth. Thus politics becomes alternative way of character development.
Another highly social work is going to be a publishing of in-game press.

listitem.para: Completely three-dimensional seamless island with highly variable content
Human-friendly interface
Advanced in-game communicative systems
First-person and third-person views with a free camera
Four different races
Classless system
Flexible system of professions
Reduced impact of levels on player's actions
Trade and exchange
Political system and social life
Citizenship system
Non-trivial crafting system
Several player communities, each with its own unique goals
Various warrior professions
Major events for players are massive military campaigns rather than random skirmishes or quests
Combat system with combos and feats
Three schools of magic

sect1.title: What to read next
sect1.para: If you want to learn more about Ireon's game design, we recommend to turn to the Software Requirements Specification.
If you are not exactly sure what do you want to read next, our Documentaion Guide may help you to make up your mind.
